case_name: Manekji Edulji Mistry Ors. v. Manekshe Ardeshir Irani Anr.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1013 of 1973 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1013 of 1973.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court Judgment and Order dated 7th September 1972 in Appeal No. 453/60.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgement and Order dated the 7th September, 1972 of the Bombay High Court at Bombay in Appeal No. 453/60 from Original Decree.

facts.text: Appellant became a tenant of the respondent for five years from 1 March 1943 on agricultural lands.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant became a tenant of the respondent for a period of five years with effect from 1 March, 1943. The tenancy was in respect of certain agricultural lands belonging to the respondent.

facts.text: Lease contained a clause for renewal for five years, not exercised by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The lease companytained a clause for renewal for five years. The appellant did number exercise the option of renewal.

facts.text: Lease expired on 28 February 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The lease expired on 28 February, 1948.

facts.text: Respondent issued notice dated 25 October 1955 terminating tenancy effective 1 April 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent by a numberice dated 25 October, 1955 terminated the tenancy with effect from 1 April, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent gave another notice on 10 June 1958 to deliver possession within 7 days.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent gave another numberice to the appellant on 10 June, 1958 without prejudice to the earlier numberice and called upon the appellant to deliver possession within 7 days.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit for possession on 14 September 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent on 14 September, 1959 filed a suit against the appellant for possession.

facts.text: Trial Court did not grant decree for possession.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court did number grant a decree for possession.

facts.text: High Court on appeal held appellant not liable to be evicted.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court also held that the appellant was number liable to be evicted.

facts.text: Supreme Court remanded to High Court for report on whether appellant was protected tenant on 1 March 1953 and entitlement to Section 5 of Amending Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, this Court remanded the matter to the High Court for a report on two questions. First, whether the appellant was a protected tenant on 1 March, 1953. Second, if the appellant was a protected tenant on 1 March, 1953 whether the appellant companyld claim benefit of Section 5 of the Amending Act, 1952.

facts.text: High Court reported appellant was protected tenant on 1 March 1953 but not entitled to Section 5 of Amending Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court submitted the report holding that the appellant was a protected tenant on 1 March, 1953 but that the appellant was number entitled to claim the benefit of section 5 of the Amending Act 1952.

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed High Court findings and set aside judgment. See Manekji Edulji Mistry Ors. v. Manekshe Ardeshir Irani Anr. 1972 1 C.R. 334.

anchor.surface_text: This Court affirmed both the findings of the High Court and set-, aside the judgment of the High Court from which an appeal had been taken to this Court.  See Manekji Edulji Mistry Ors. v. Manekshe Ardeshir Irani Anr. 1972 1 C.R. 334 .

facts.text: Supreme Court directed High Court to determine valid termination of tenancy as damages issues pending.

anchor.surface_text: This Court at the invitation of the parties directed the High Court to determine whether there was a valid termination of tenancy because there were two issues as to damages yet to be decided.

facts.text: High Court on remand held appellant not entitled to notice and was tenant on sufferance; damages not yet heard.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on remand has held that the appellant was number entitled to any numberice and that the appellant was a tenant on sufferance,, The issues as to damages are number yet heard.

facts.text: Under section 23(1)(b) of Bombay Tenancy Act 1939 as amended 1946, lease deemed for not less than ten years, expired 28 February 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 23 1  b  of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 as it stood amended in 1946, every lease subsisting on the date when that section came into force became deemed to be for a period of number less than ten years. The effect of the statutory provision was that the appellants lease which would have expired on 28 February, 1948 expired on 28 February, 1953

facts.text: Landlord did not make application under section 3A of 1939 Act as modified by 1948 Act, so appellant became protected tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord in the present case did number make any application as companytemplated in section 3A of the 1939 Act as modified by the 1948 Act. The result was that the appellant became a protected tenant by virtue of the 1948 Act read with section 3A of the 1939 Act.

facts.text: Appellant remained protected tenant from 1 March 1953 until 31 July 1956.

anchor.surface_text: From 1 March, 1953 until 31 July, 1956 the appellant remained a protected tenant under the 1948 Act until section 88B was introduced in the 1948 Act by Act 13 of 1956.

facts.text: Section 88B introduced by Act 13 of 1956 made appellant no longer protected tenant from 1 August 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of introduction of section 88B in the 1948 Act was that the appellant numberlonger remained a protected tenant. ... After the appellant ceased to be protected tenant on 1 August, 1956

facts.text: No consent by respondent for appellant to hold over; appellant tenant on sufferance.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said that the respondent assented to the appellant companytinuing in possession on the same terms and companyditions as in the original tenancy. ... In the present case, there is numberdoubt that the appellant did number have any companysent and the respondent never gave any companysent to hold over. The appellant remained in possession on sufferance.

facts.text: Lands are property of a Trust registered under Bombay Public Trust Act 1950; income appropriated for trust purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The Trust has to satisfy two companyditions. First, the Trust is registered under the Bombay Public Trust Act, 1950. Second, the entire income of the lands which are the property of the Trust is appropriated for the purposes of such Trust.

facts.text: Collector held inquiry under section 88B(2) and granted certificate to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: A companytention was advanced on behalf of the appellant that he appellant was entitled to a numberice when the Collector held an inquiry under section 88B 2  of the Act for the purpose of granting a certificate to the respondent.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's contention for notice in Collector inquiry; inquiry between Collector and Trust.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court did number accept the companytention. The High Court held that the appellant at numberstage denied the fact that the lands are the property of a Trust. The inquiry is between the Collector and the Trust.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: For those reasons, the appeal is dismissed.

section 4B of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 hereinafter referred to as the 1948 Act. Section 4B states that no tenancy of any land shall be terminated merely on the ground that the period fixed by agreement or usage for its duration has expired.

concepts.interpretation: Does not apply where there is no tenancy, as the appellant is a tenant on sufferance without landlord's consent.

It is only where a tenant will continue in possession with the consent of the landlord that he can be called a tenant holding over or a tenant at will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 5 provides relief to tenants other than protected tenants; affirmed High Court finding.

holdings.text: Every lease subsisting became deemed for not less than ten years under section 23(1)(b) of Bombay Tenancy Act 1939, extending lease to 28 February 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 23 1  b  of the Bombay Tenancy Act, 1939 as it stood amended in 1946, every lease subsisting on the date when that section came into force became deemed to be for a period of number less than ten years. The effect of the statutory provision was that the appellants lease which would have expired on 28 February, 1948 expired on 28 February, 1953

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory deeming provision to facts.

holdings.text: The appellant became a protected tenant by virtue of the 1948 Act read with section 3A of the 1939 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord failed to apply for declaration otherwise; deeming under s.3A.

holdings.text: Introduction of section 88B made the appellant no longer a protected tenant from 1 August 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of introduction of section 88B in the 1948 Act was that the appellant numberlonger remained a protected tenant. Along with section 88B was introduced section 4A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.88B withdraws protection for qualifying trust lands; s.4A excludes such tenancies.

holdings.text: Section 4A does not apply to tenancies governed by section 88B(1).

The expression holding over is used in the sense of retaining possession. If a tenant after the termination of the lease is in possession without the companysent of the landlord, he is a tenant by sufferance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common law: holding over requires landlord consent; absent consent post-term, sufferance; no privity.

holdings.text: Section 4B has no application because there is no tenancy; appellant is a trespasser.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore section 4B of the Act has numberapplication because there is numbertenancy. Tenancy is a matter of privity of parties. If there is numberconsent, the appellant is a trespasser.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4B presupposes tenancy; tenant on sufferance lacks privity/consent, no tenancy exists.

holdings.text: Appellant not entitled to notice in Collector inquiry under section 88B(2); certificate is conclusive evidence.
